section-block.rac_essential-question: What do we do during the day and at night?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Jane Smiley and illustrated by Lauren Castillo
section-block.rac_book_summary: This story features Lucy, a little girl who spends the day at the beach with her mom and dad. By the end of the day, everyone is yawning. But that night, Lucy has trouble falling asleep. As you read, take breaks to count yawns and to discuss the passing of time.

section-block.rac_body-text: Practice rote counting forward to and backward from 30 as a class. Ask for volunteers to count solo, too!
Have children count to twenty one at a time around the circle. Challenge children to pretend to yawn as they count. Can they still say the number?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This book is called Twenty Yawns. Who remembers what the word yawn means? (MB)
Let’s count to 20 together.
What is Lucy doing? Have you ever dug a hole on the beach? What was your trip to the beach like? (MB)
What is Lucy doing now?
How can you tell that it is daytime in this picture?
How many birds do you see in this picture? Let’s count them.
There are 16 z’s above Lucy’s mom’s head! We use a /z/ sound to show that someone is asleep and snoring.
Let’s count to 16 together.
How many letter r’s do you see in this word? What sound does r make?
Very is usually spelled with only one r, but the author spelled it with five to make it seem very important. Have you ever had to be verrrrry quiet? Why?
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one thing Lucy does during the day?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to select several children to share their responses with the class.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Yawning in class is natural, but in some cases children become tired from the effort it takes to stay focused. Give these children multiple opportunities to get up and move. Physical activity helps children stay more alert and engaged.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Working Memory

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Memory is very important. When you remember where you last played with a toy, it’s much easier to find the toy when you want to play with it again. When we remember what happened in a book, we can talk about it with our friends. You use your memory every day! What is one thing that you remember about the book Twenty Yawns?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Twenty Yawns by Jane Smiley and illustrated by Lauren Castillo. We will talk about how the characters use their memory.
Clifford loves to use his memory! When he reads a story, he works hard to remember everything that happens so he can talk about it with his friends afterward.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Focus on Counting: Pause to have children count items on the page.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The beach umbrella is making a flapping sound in the breeze. Who can count how many times we see the word flap on the page?
Lucy and her parents are going home. What do you need to remember when you are ready to go home from a trip? (MB)
Lucy’s mom uses her memory to read. She remembers the sounds the letters make.
Do you remember what letter makes the sound at the beginning of the name Fred? (MB)
How is Lucy using her memory on this page?
How many stuffed animals does Lucy have?
How many people did Lucy draw in her pictures? How does Lucy use her memory as she looks at her pictures?
Are Lucy’s pictures and stuffed animals really yawning? How do you know?

section.rac_body-text: Play a memory game. Have children sit in a circle, and have the first child complete the sentence frame: In my room there is a ____ . Repeat the sentence as a class. Then, have the next child add to the sentence: In my room there is a [object just named] and a ____ . Repeat the new sentence as a class. Continue around the circle until every child has had a turn to name an object. Can anyone remember all of the objects?
Transcribe children’s speech as they recall and name things Lucy did during her day on the beach.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: One way to help children strengthen their working memory is to suggest they form a mental picture of what they’ve heard or seen or what they’re trying to remember. For example, if you’re talking about the numbers two and three, suggest that the child “see” two suns or three moons. (ADD Resource Center, 2017)

section-block.rac_body-text: Build one tower using 10 Connecting Cubes and another tower using only two cubes. Discuss how long it took to build each tower. Which tower took longer to build?
Play a game of Simon Says. As Simon, give directions using long and quick. For example: Simon Says take a quick step. Simon Says blink a long blink. Clap a quick clap.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Twenty Yawns by Jane Smiley and illustrated by Lauren Castillo.
Lala loves reading stories that are made up, like this one.
As we read today, think about this question: Why does Lucy bring her stuffed animals to bed?

section.rac_body-text: Facilitate back-and-forth conversation to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Lucy and her parents walked to the end of the beach. Do you think that took a long time? Why?
Lucy got dizzy! Dizzy is when your head feels like it’s spinning. Have you ever been dizzy after doing something too quickly? (MB)
Mom fell asleep while reading! Do you think it took a long time to fall asleep, or did she fall asleep quickly? How can you tell?
Can you say how many pictures Lucy has on her wall without counting them one by one?
Suddenly is another way of saying something happened quickly. Why do you think Lucy is awake? Is it day yet, or is it still night?
Have you ever been awake at night? What did that feel like? (MB)
Lucy is being very quiet. Do you think she took a long time to cross the room, or was she quick?
Do you remember when we talked about the word very on this page? What letter did the author write too many of? (MB)
Listen to how I say the word. Did I take a long time to say it?
Lonely is how you feel when you want to be with other people, but no one is around. How many toys does Lucy think look lonely? Let’s count.
Did you listen and remember as we read today? Why does Lucy bring her stuffed animals to bed?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to select several children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Lucy brings them to bed because she is awake.
Lucy brings them to bed to help her sleep.
Lucy brings them to bed because she thinks they look lonely.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about things we do at night.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Lucy bring her stuffed animals to bed to help her sleep?
Lucy brings stuffed animals to bed to help her sl___ (sleep).
Lucy brings stuffed animals to bed to help her sleep.
Do you have a favorite toy that you sleep with?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Duration is tricky for preschoolers. Children may understand that an event happened in the past, but use yesterday to indicate two days (or even two months) ago. Help children understand the concept of a long time by explaining time in context. For example, explain that eating lunch takes longer than eating a snack.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | WEEK 1: Day and Night

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss day and night as a class. Point out that in Twenty Yawns, Lucy did some things during the day and some at night. What did Lucy do during the day? During the night?
Play a game of statues using the words day and night. When you say “day,” children act out a daytime activity. When you say “night,” children quickly pretend to sleep.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to read Daytime/Nighttime. It is an informational poster full of facts.
Twenty Yawns and Daytime/Nighttime both tell about day and night. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read.
What do we do during the day and at night?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Day and Night
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions and talk about the passing of time.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The sky is blue! Do you think it is day or night?
What sounds do you hear in the word mountains? Who remembers what mountains are? (MB)
How can you tell that it is night in this picture?
Do you think it will take a long time for the train to get home, or will the trip be quick? Why?
What letter sound does country begin with? Do you remember what country means? (MB)
Let’s count the cows in the field.
Fireflies are insects that glow. How many can you see in this picture? Let’s count.
How many wheels are on the baby carriage? Let’s count.
Does it take a long or short time for day to turn to night? How can you tell it is night in this picture?

section.rac_body-text: Have children sit in a circle. Ask children to think of one activity they like to do in their home during the day. Then ask them to think of one activity they like to do in their home at night. Invite volunteers to stand up and describe their activities using the sentence frame: When it is ____ (day/night), I like to _____ .
Provide a writing prompt about day or night, and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Teaching Night and Day
section-block.rac_child_development_body: You can start to build on children’s understanding of day and night with a very brief science lesson. Explain that the Earth is always turning. When one side faces toward the sun, the other side faces away from the sun. For the side facing the sun, it is day. For the side facing away from the sun, it is night. Use a ball to help children visualize the basic idea.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | WEEK 1: Day and Night

section-block.rac_body-text: Name events in the story and have children say whether the event happened during the day or night. (“That event happened during the day.” “That happened at night.”)
Invite children to act out a day activity and a night activity. Have other children name the activity and say whether it’s done during the day or at night.
Grab a random number of Connecting Cubes. Have children guess how many cubes there are. Then, call on a child to come up and count. Closest guess wins!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Twenty Yawns by Jane Smiley and illustrated by Lauren Castillo one more time this week.
Lala the Lizard wonders whether this book teaches us information or tells a story. Do you remember?
We have learned a lot about day and night this week. When we read today, think about this question: What is your favorite thing to do during the day?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement: As children act out the story, encourage them to think about language that describes the passing of time.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s all count to 20 one more time! Let’s count to 20 quickly and then take a long time to count back down to one.
The umbrella is flapping in the breeze! Who can sound out the word flap?
Let’s pretend to flap our arms in the breeze. Move them back and forth very quickly!
Let’s pretend to take a long walk on the beach during the day. What can you see?
Now let’s pretend to walk on the beach at night. How is it different?
How many people are yawning in this picture? Who can come to the book and count?
Let’s pretend to take a long time to yawn.
Lucy is going to bed. Will she fall asleep quickly? Who remembers what happens next? (MB)
Let’s pretend to pull on our pajamas and climb into bed.
How many toys is Lucy tucking into bed? Who can come to the book and count?
Let’s pretend to tuck our toys in for the night. Give them a quick kiss and whisper “good night!”
What is your favorite thing to do during the day?
section.rac_body-text: Ask children to Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to pick two or three children to share with the class.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: My favorite thing to do during the day is to play outside.
My favorite thing to do during the day is to go to school.
My favorite thing to do during the day is to see my friends.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about day or night.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you like playing during the day or seeing friends?
My favorite thing to do during the day is to pl__ _ (play).
My favorite thing to do during the day is to play.
What is your favorite thing to do at night?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: You can help multilingual learners by frequently revisiting key words in their home language. When words like day, night, home, and school are said during the lesson, have the child say the word in his or her home language and in English. Gradually encourage children to use the English word more to help them become comfortable using it.
